awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Illuminating the Early Universe with Dark Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award funds the research activities of Professor Adrienne Erickcek at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.  

Observations of the oldest light in the Universe indicate that there was a period of accelerated expansion, called inflation, shortly after the Big Bang.  During inflation, quantum fluctuations in the energy density of the Universe were imprinted on cosmological scales, seeding the structures that eventually became galaxies.  We do not know why inflation happened or why it ended.  Moreover, inflation left the Universe devoid of all matter and radiation, yet the measured abundances of light elements imply that the Universe was filled with extremely hot radiation one second after inflation ended.  Professor Erickcek aims to fill this gap in the cosmological record by studying the smallest gravitationally bound clumps of dark matter, which is an unknown source of mass that currently makes up about 25% of the energy density of the Universe.   In addition to improving our understanding of the early Universe and the properties of dark matter --- thus advancing the national interest by promoting the progress of science --- this project will also have significant broader impacts.  Graduate and undergraduate students will contribute to this investigation and will receive training both in physical cosmology and in widely applicable mathematical and computational techniques.  Professor Erickcek will also bring the excitement of this research to high-school students by working with educators at the Morehead Planetarium and Science Center to develop an inquiry-based curriculum module that incorporates the evidence for dark matter into lessons on Newtonian mechanics, thereby exposing students to one of the great mysteries of cosmology.  This module will be made publicly available, and Professor Erickcek will lead professional-development workshops at North Carolina teaching conferences to train high-school teachers to use this module in their classrooms.  Finally, Professor Erickcek will share her research with the general public by hosting Morehead's Carolina Science Cafe and Teen Science Cafe.

More specifically, the smallest and earliest-forming dark matter halos provide a window into the gap between inflation and the hot Big Bang because their abundance is affected by the properties of the density fluctuations created during the final stages of inflation and the evolution of the Universe during its first second.  Professor Erickcek will extend her prior work on how gamma-ray observations constrain thermal dark-matter production during an early matter-dominated era to other thermal histories and dark-matter creation mechanisms.  This investigation will narrow the field of potential dark-matter candidates by restricting their production mechanisms and breaking the degeneracy between relic abundance and thermal history.  In particular, it will determine if gravitationally coupled moduli fields with masses around the TeV scale are compatible with neutralino dark matter, and may rule out super-heavy hidden-sector particles as dark-matter candidates.  This investigation will also determine how enhanced small-scale inhomogeneity generated during inflation affects the microhalo abundance and the dark-matter annihilation rate.  Professor Erickcek's group will then derive robust constraints on small-scale primordial fluctuations that will improve our understanding of inflation.  Both of these tasks will utilize small-box, high-redshift simulations of microhalo formation.  Finally, Professor Erickcek will explore how observations of the cosmic microwave background, 21cm tomography, and measurements of the temperature of the intergalactic medium may expose the existence of early-forming microhalos and allow us to close this gap in our understanding of the early Universe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a gap in our understanding of the expansion history of the universe: we do not know how the universe evolved during its first second. There is considerable evidence that the universe underwent a period of accelerated expansion at its inception, but we do not know how the universe evolved between the end of this inflationary period and the onset of Big Bang nucleosynthesis (BBN). The investigation funded by this award determined how the smallest gravitationally bound structures, called microhalos, can be used to probe this epoch.  An early accomplishment of this investigation was the invention of a new method to predict the abundance and density profiles of microhalos from the statistical properties of the initial density fluctuations. This technique allows us to characterize the microhalo population that arises from any cosmological history directly from the initial spectrum of density fluctuations.

The second objective of this investigation was to improve our understanding of how the evolution of the early universe affects the initial density fluctuations. If there was an early matter-dominated era (EMDE) before BBN, density fluctuations on scales small enough to evolve during the EMDE are enhanced.  We determined how the range of scales with enhanced fluctuations depends on the properties of the particles that dominated the universe during the EMDE. The pressure associated with these particles suppresses the growth of density fluctuations, and we showed how the spectrum of fluctuations can be used to probe these particles' masses and self-interactions.  We also investigated how the decay of a heavy particle shortly after BBN impacts density fluctuations in the early universe, and we used observations of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and other cosmological probes to establish limits on how much such a particle can affect the universe's expansion rate.

The third objective of this investigation was to use astronomical observations to constrain the microhalo population and the origins of dark matter.  Over 80% of the matter in the universe cannot be found on the periodic table, and it is generally assumed that this dark matter was produced during the universe's first second. Our ignorance of this epoch severely limits our understanding of dark matter. In this investigation, we considered two possible production mechanisms for dark matter: nonthermal production from the decay of a heavier particle and thermal production from a hot radiation bath. We showed how nonthermal production imparts dark matter particles with velocities that inhibit the formation of small structures, and we used observations of the smallest luminous structures to establish the first constraints on the nonthermal production of dark matter during an EMDE. If dark matter is produced thermally, then dark matter particles annihilate when they collide. We calculated how the microhalo population arising from an EMDE or a period of kination (during which the universe was dominated by a fast-evolving scalar field) enhances the dark matter annihilation rate. We then used gamma-ray observations to constrain dark matter production during an EMDE and during a period of kination. We also explored how observations of the CMB and the temperature of the intergalactic medium can constrain dark matter annihilation within early forming microhalos. We found that these probes are not as constraining as the isotropic gamma-ray background.

This award provided support to seven graduate students and four undergraduate students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.  This award also funded the development of an inquiry-based curriculum module that guides high school students to the discovery of dark matter. The PI collaborated with a curriculum developer at the Morehead Science Center to create this module, which is titled "How do You Weigh a Galaxy?" The first component of the curriculum consists of a hands-on exploration of circular motion: students use photogates to measure the circular velocity of a ball as it is pulled by a radial force to probe the relationship between centripetal force, velocity, and radius.  The second component applies this understanding of circular motion to the orbits of planets in the Solar System, leading to the formulation of Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation.  Finally, students use both concepts to compute the masses of spiral galaxies from their rotational velocities, thus discovering that galaxies contain far more mass than contained in their visible stars and gas.  The PI taught this module to over 100 students at local high schools, and she trained other high school teachers to use this curriculum in their own classes.  She also shared her quest to understand dark matter more broadly by giving several public presentations.
